main event: A round, silver object similar to a half-moon, about 60 feet in diameter, was observed by a trained observer and tracked on radar in Burbank, California on August 14, 1958.
interesting points: The object moved at random and disappeared after 6-7 minutes of observation.
A silver or vapor-like area was observed behind the object, which varied in color from greenish to whitish.
The object was first seen 43 degrees off the horizon, moving southeast, then turned further south before turning north and fading out of sight.
The sighting was made by a trained observer and the object was tracked on radar, though the observer's statements were described as inconsistent and confusing.
A weather balloon was released from a nearby airport around the same time, but it is noted that no cause could be determined for the sighting.
sighted object: a round, silver object similar to a half-moon, about 60 feet in diameter
photographs: yes, the report indicates that photographs were taken
